question_text: Calculate the reaction wave velocity u for a hotspot with a temperature gradient of -1.5 K/mm and an IDT sensitivity ∂τi/∂T of -0.2 ms/K. Explain the physical meaning of the negative signs in the parameters and discuss how this velocity relates to autoignition propagation modes according to the Zeldovich classification, including realistic physical constraints on combustion wave speeds based on the provided paper content.
standard_answer: The reaction wave velocity u is calculated using the formula: u = (∂τi/∂T)^(-1) × (∂T/∂r). Given ∂τi/∂T = -0.2 ms/K and ∂T/∂r = -1.5 K/mm, first convert units consistently: ∂τi/∂T = -0.0002 s/K, ∂T/∂r = -1500 K/m. Taking the inverse: (∂τi/∂T)^(-1) = (-0.0002 s/K)^(-1) = -5000 K/s. Then u = (-5000 K/s) × (-1500 K/m) = 7,500,000 m/s. The negative signs have important physical meaning: ∂τi/∂T is negative because ignition delay time decreases with increasing temperature (higher temperature accelerates chemical kinetics), while ∂T/∂r is negative because temperature decreases with distance from the hotspot center (thermal gradient outward from the hottest point). When multiplied, the two negatives yield a positive velocity, indicating outward propagation from the hotspot. According to the Zeldovich classification, propagation modes range from: thermal explosion (ξ = 0), supersonic autoignitive wave (ξl > ξ > 0), developing detonation (ξu > ξ ≥ ξl), subsonic autoignitive deflagration (a/SL > ξ ≥ ξu), to subsonic laminar burning (ξ ≥ a/SL). The calculated value of 7,500,000 m/s exceeds practical combustion wave speeds significantly - laminar flames propagate at 0.1-1 m/s, turbulent flames at 1-100 m/s, and detonation waves at 1500-2000 m/s. This unrealistically high value suggests the input parameters represent an extreme case not physically realizable in engine combustion, where thermal gradients and IDT sensitivities are constrained by practical combustion physics and heat transfer limitations.

original_text.1: The reaction wave velocity is inversely proportional to the gradient of IDT with respect to the distance r from the center of a hotspot. u = ( ∂τi / ∂r )^(-1)
original_text.2: This can be rewritten with the IDT sensitivity and temperature gradient: u = ( ∂τi / ∂T )^(-1) × ( ∂T / ∂r )
original_text.3: The classification of propagation modes after autoignition was presented by Zeldovich [90] as follows: - u > DCJ > a: Propagation of a weak detonation wave. - DCJ ≥ u > a: Detonation with a compressing shock wave. - a > u > uf: Subsonic propagation. - uf > u: Flame development generated by diffusion and heat conduction.

However, the answer fails to recognize that this velocity (7,500,000 m/s) is physically impossible as it exceeds the speed of light (~300,000,000 m/s) by a factor of 25, indicating the input parameters are unrealistic.
